title: How to Make a Stackable Cloth Baby Toy

steps.headline: Choose a fabric that matches or complements the baby room style.
steps.description: If the child’s mother has her baby’s room decked out in animal print or loves pink, pay homage to her design choice by picking fabrics that matches her taste. Make sure you have enough fabric to create a 3”, 5” and 7” square (front and back).

steps.headline: Purchase thread that will compliment the fabric style.
steps.description: Also, if you are hand sewing the toy, don’t forget to pick up sewing needles.

steps.headline: Find a sharp pair of sewing scissors and a measuring tape to help you with precise fabric measurements.
Purchase cotton filling or cotton balls.
steps.description: You will need enough to stuff all three toys.

steps.headline: Cut out your squares.
steps.description: You will need to cut out two 3”, two 5” and two 7” squares. Make sure the squares match up perfectly so you don’t end up with a crooked toy.

steps.headline: Turn the fabric back to back so the backside of the fabric is facing outward.
steps.description: You will be sewing the fabric while its “inside out” and then turning it right side out for stuffing.

steps.headline: Sew the 7” square’s long sides and one of the short sides.
steps.description: Leave approximately a 1/2” seam along the edges. Repeat this step for the 5” and the 3” squares.

steps.headline: Turn all three fabric squares right side out.
steps.description: Trim any loose fabric or strings.

steps.headline: Stuff the fabric squares with cotton filling.
steps.description: Don’t overfill as you will need to still sew the final short side. But make sure the squares are well plumped.

steps.headline: Sew the short side of each fabric square using the same inch seam work as you did for the other fabric square sides.
Trim any loose fabric/thread before wrapping and/or giving to the baby.

text: Select Fabrics and Supplies Choose a fabric that matches or complements the baby room style. If the child’s mother has her baby’s room decked out in animal print or loves pink, pay homage to her design choice by picking fabrics that matches her taste. Make sure you have enough fabric to create a 3”, 5” and 7” square (front and back). Purchase thread that will compliment the fabric style. Also, if you are hand sewing the toy, don’t forget to pick up sewing needles. Find a sharp pair of sewing scissors and a measuring tape to help you with precise fabric measurements.  Purchase cotton filling or cotton balls. You will need enough to stuff all three toys. Create Toy Cut out your squares. You will need to cut out two 3”, two 5” and two 7” squares. Make sure the squares match up perfectly so you don’t end up with a crooked toy. Turn the fabric back to back so the backside of the fabric is facing outward. You will be sewing the fabric while its “inside out” and then turning it right side out for stuffing. Sew the 7” square’s long sides and one of the short sides. Leave approximately a 1/2” seam along the edges. Repeat this step for the 5” and the 3” squares. Turn all three fabric squares right side out. Trim any loose fabric or strings. Stuff the fabric squares with cotton filling. Don’t overfill as you will need to still sew the final short side. But make sure the squares are well plumped. Sew the short side of each fabric square using the same inch seam work as you did for the other fabric square sides.  Trim any loose fabric/thread before wrapping and/or giving to the baby.  Done.
